As for the five kinds of mind, the first is the mind of great compassion.
One should hold this mind firmly and not abandon it, thinking of the evil destinies and the sentient beings in the hells, and further contemplating their suffering as explained in the sutras.
You should know it now, and I will explain it again for you in this sutra.

The fire wraps around from the head to the feet - the bodies of the beings in this hell are
soft and weak, like ripe butter, and are burned by the many fires that crisscross and heat.
The hell fire burns the human fire, like burning cotton flowers with no remaining ashes.
Some beings are burned by the fire and run around seeking rescue, not knowing what to do;
Some beings have nowhere to escape and return to the fire;
Some beings are suddenly thrown into a deep pit of filth, in which there are insects with sharp beaks, all copper and iron sixteen inches long, pecking at the beings' skin, bones, marrow, and brains;
Some beings are burned and cooked in the smoldering embers;
Some beings are drowned in the salty water.
At that time, the jailers use a large iron net to scoop them out from the middle, like catching fish, and place the beings on the hot iron ground to lie down and be burned.
Next, iron pincers are used to pull out their tongues, and molten copper is poured into their mouths. They faint and die, only to revive after a long time.
They then try to flee in search of escape, but there is no way out.
There is also an iron dog that chases after them. Iron crows with iron beaks fly and peck at them, splitting their bones and flesh and devouring them.
Seeing a garden in the distance, they try to climb up in hopes of escape. In the trees of that garden, iron thorns grow, each sixteen inches long, and they are burning hot.
When the beings try to climb up, the thorns point downward, piercing their chests and coming out through their backs. They suffer immeasurable pain, but there is no way to escape.
Crows and vultures fly down and peck out their eyes, then split open their skulls to eat the brain.
When they try to come down, the thorns point upward, and their eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, flesh, hands, feet, and ten fingers are all scattered and hang on the trees, with no way to escape.
The jailers would seize them, put them in iron bags, and beat them with hot iron rods back and forth.
There were also sentient beings whose hands, feet, head, and topknot were all torn apart and sawed through.
There were also sentient beings in iron mortars, pounded from the head with iron pestles.
There were also sentient beings in cauldrons of boiling water, turned over with iron forks and cooked until rotten, with only bones remaining, yet their lives still continued.
There were also sentient beings in hell, who were made into houses with purple ore, set on fire, and the flames blazed through, with molten purple ore dripping like hot arrows.

There was also a hell with iron mountains on four sides, and sentient beings in between the two mountains were squeezed, sometimes to the north and south or east and west. When the two mountains came together, pus and blood flowed out from the sentient beings in between.

There is also a hell where iron snakes wrap around the bodies of sentient beings from head to foot, and bite their heads, binding them with all their strength, and the marrow and blood gather at the top, where they suck and eat them, leaving only the skin and bones.

There is also a hell where the various sentient beings are pierced by the wardens with an iron trident, entering from the two feet to the top of the head and the shoulders, coming out from three places, and the fire follows the piercing, with fierce flames bursting forth, and fire also comes out from the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth.

There is also a hell where the various sentient beings lie on a hot iron ground, either lying down or lying on their sides, and then black iron ropes are stretched along their bodies, and they are then chopped with axes, like craftsmen working on wet wood.

There are also sentient beings who are skinned by the wardens from the feet to the head, and after skinning them, the skin is made into reins and bridles, and the sentient beings are put on the top of a high mountain, where they are driven to climb with hot iron, whipped and beaten in myriad ways, suffering indescribably.

These sentient beings, from beginningless time, have all been my parents, relatives inside and outside. Now, they are wandering in the hells, constantly experiencing suffering for immeasurable eons, as if in their own homes. Due to the exhaustion of evil karma, they temporarily take rebirth as humans or gods, but create offenses here and fall back into the hells.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, observing these sentient beings undergoing various sufferings, give rise to a mind of great compassion.
Next, they contemplate the realm of hungry ghosts and again give rise to a compassionate mind.

They see that sentient beings dwelling among hungry ghosts, one day and night is equivalent to one month for humans. Calculating by days, twelve months is one year. In the realm of hungry ghosts, they live for five hundred years, equivalent to fifteen thousand years in the human realm. They constantly experience hunger and thirst, and have never heard the name of drink with their ears, let alone see it with their eyes.

However, their bodies are like large mountains, their heads like tents, their throats as thin as needles, their hair hanging down covering both shoulders, like sharp knives cutting their bodies, turning into fierce flames burning their bodies, like fire burning firewood, the pain is hard to endure, the hair in their armpits covering their waist and abdomen, the hair in their private parts hanging down to their knees and ankles, cutting with knives and burning with fire is also like this, experiencing such suffering for countless years.

Sometimes seeing water from afar, they rush to seek it, but when they arrive, they fall face down, and by the power of evil karma, the water turns into pus, blood, feces, and filth, or becomes hot sand.

On both banks of the water, there are also jail guards holding bows, arrows, knives, clubs, axes, spears, and halberds, chopping, stabbing, and beating in various ways. Burning with the fire of hunger and confused by intense thirst, they return and run wildly, burned by the fierce fire, not knowing where to go.
The jail guards chase after them, beating, chopping, and cutting, breaking all their limbs and joints.

There were also hungry ghosts who gave birth to five children in the morning and ate them as they were born, and at night gave birth to five more children and ate them as they were born. They were always hungry and never had a moment of satisfaction.

If they encountered rain from the heavens, they would tilt their heads up to receive it, but by the power of their karma, not a single drop would enter their mouths. Instead, it would flow into their bellies and transform into a raging fire, passing straight through and coming out.

If they encountered a hot wind rising during the hot summer months, by the power of their karma the hungry ghosts would be blown like flying dust onto a sandy desert, burned by the hot sand below and scorched by the sun above. Driven by hunger, thirst, and heat, they would see a forest in the distance and rush towards it, hoping to find some shade to cool off. But wherever they went, the shade would always move away from them.
Why is this?

In the past, when they were human beings, they may have been pure and free from clouds, allowing the light to shine and touch them. But the scorching heat would burn their bodies, just like the summer sun in full blaze.

There were also hungry ghosts who, during the coldest winter months, encountered a great wind. By the power of their karma, they were blown like flying dust onto an icy mountain, where they suffered from the cold.

From there, they experience suffering for immeasurable time. When their life ends there, they fall back into hell. In this way, they go back and forth for immeasurable years. Only when their evil karma is exhausted do they rarely attain a human body, but are born into a poor family, stingy and not giving. They live by begging, becoming even more greedy and miserly.

Because of their poverty, they commit the ten kinds of unwholesome actions and various other offenses. When their life ends from this, they fall back into hell and experience various kinds of suffering.
When their suffering ends there, they are born among hungry ghosts. In this way, they go back and forth for countless eons, experiencing such suffering.

These beings have also been my parents, relatives, and loved ones in the past, throughout immeasurable and boundless eons of birth and death. They have always committed unwholesome actions for my sake and are now experiencing the suffering of retribution as hungry ghosts.
The Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva, observing this suffering, gives rise to a mind of great compassion.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
The realm of hungry ghosts being so, next contemplate the animals in the same way.

There are various animals such as deer, wild dogs, foxes, rabbits, tigers, leopards, jackals, wolves, and other beasts, as well as various flying birds such as wild chickens, geese, ducks, drakes, geese, and mandarin ducks. These kinds of creatures, whether walking or still, resting or flying, are always afraid of humans, powerful birds and beasts. Whether drinking or eating, they are never at ease, always fearful day and night.
There are also aquatic creatures such as alligators, turtles, frogs, fish, clams, shrimp, and maá¹‡i fish. These kinds of creatures are constantly caught in nets, living and dying in the water.
There are also creatures such as snakes, vipers, lizards, newts, centipedes, rats, and mongooses. These kinds of creatures are born in the dark and die in the dark.
There are also creatures such as lice, fleas, and ticks that are born on the human body and die on the human body.

There are also animals that are born and die right where they are, either on corpses, in damp filth, or on grass and trees, or they are born and die through transformation, such as maggots, butterflies, and locusts.

There are also animals that always eat pus, blood, and various impurities as if they were sweet flavors, such as pigs, dogs, dung beetles, and flies. They smell the foul stench from afar and consider it fragrant and delicious, flying and crawling to it in haste for fear of not getting to eat.
There are also animals that do not eat tender grass but only thorny plants, and do not drink clear water but only turbid water.

There are also animals that do not grow on grass but always eat grass, such as elephants, horses, cows, donkeys, camels, mules, and other livestock. They are hooked in the brain with iron hooks to make them tame and then ridden. Their noses are pierced, they are bridled and reined, their heads are tethered, they carry heavy loads while walking, and they are constantly whipped and scolded to go fast or slow. Some are weak and fall down after getting up, beaten without limit, unable to move forward. All this is due to their past karma, which they now suffer.
Or they eat the offerings of faith without any further diligence, repaying others' past debts and encountering this hardship.
Thus driven and whipped in various ways, they have not yet repaid enough, or are killed, suffering myriad hardships with nowhere to appeal.
Born lacking water and grass, sick without medicine, they die and are skinned and eaten by others.
Having died like this, they fall into hell.
Why is it so?

Due to the stupidity of the mind, not knowing good from evil, not thinking of the parents who gave birth and nurtured with effort, not understanding cause and effect, not hearing the true Dharma, and also lacking the wholesome roots of giving and keeping precepts, they only think of water and grass, knowing nothing else.
These animals are raised by humans.

Apart from those raised, the other types of animals, namely lions, tigers, leopards, wolves, and the water and land animals mentioned above, harm and eat each other. Due to this karma, they are born in the hells, experiencing severe suffering for innumerable eons. When their hellish offenses are exhausted, they again enter the animal realm, coming and going like this for innumerable eons.

These animals have also been parents, relatives, and family members in the past, for innumerable and boundless eons of birth and death. They have always created unwholesome karma for my sake and are now in the animal realm experiencing this painful retribution.
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, upon observing this suffering, give rise to a mind of great compassion.
Having contemplated the animal realm in this way, next contemplate the human realm.

There are sentient beings who, although born in the human realm, experience much poverty and hunger. For a long time they go naked, walking in mud, sleeping in the rain, harvesting in the frost, weeding in the heat, driven day and night. Their hands and feet are cracked, their hair is disheveled, and they walk emaciated, begging from door to door, never having a single full meal. By nightfall, they lie down hungry and sleep. No one helps them in obtaining provisions.

Although they speak and act, people do not believe or follow them. Although they have a good appearance, they are on the contrary treated with contempt. They always practice patience and benefit others, but are resented and scolded, saying they are timid.
Some have literary skills but are not recorded by others. When visiting relatives, they are suspicious and dislike them, seeking food.
Some take refuge in the Three Jewels but are slandered as seeking fame, or when praising others, they are said to be flattering.

Or born in a low class, always not at ease, bound to others, advancing and retreating only by the order, always enduring cold and heat, not knowing warmth and coolness, drawing water and gathering firewood, not complaining of weariness.
The master's mind has no compassion at all. If there is a slight delay, he is soon beaten.
One's own actions bring their own consequences, not given by heaven or others. The retribution of meager blessings is worse than the suffering of death.
It is like a withered tree with no branches or leaves. No flying birds come to roost. A person of meager blessings is also like this.

Furthermore, Maitreya!
One should know that poverty is extremely great suffering.
Although they always associate with and praise others, due to lack of merit, faults arise. Due to poverty, they are constantly humiliated and create more evil karma, falling into the hells.

Moreover, there are people of noble and distinguished families with many servants, elephants, horses, cows, and sheep, surrounded by relatives and loved ones, enjoying supreme bliss like the gods. Deluded by the five desires, they increase greed and anger, always giving rise to arrogance and looking down upon others.
At that time, the Blessed One spoke a verse, saying:

Addicted to the five desires like a drunkard, whether noble or humble, all attract the suffering of birth and death.
The Buddha told Maitreya Bodhisattva MahÄsattva:

All sentient beings do not know the present and future, and their own created karma follows them like a shadow. The cause of suffering is rooted in greed and desire. They do not cultivate the ferry and bridge of wholesome dharmas, and burn away the causes of past wholesome dharmas, exhausting them all. After passing away from here, they fall back into the three evil paths.
Why is it so?

Because of greed and desire, they constantly take life, relying on their own power to rob others of their wealth, using various methods to violate others' wives and concubines, indulging in sexual misconduct without regard for relatives or strangers, constantly giving rise to desires and telling lies, deceptively appearing kind and adorning their words with ornate phrases, reviling sentient beings with harsh words, spreading rumors to divide others, not reconciling relatives and close associates, constantly harboring greed and jealousy, and arrogantly exalting themselves. They do not know the profound kindness of the Three Jewels from past lives, that for immeasurable eons they diligently cultivated superior practices and accumulated the provisions for enlightenment, becoming omniscient and called a Buddha, serving as a lamp in the long night of birth and death, as a refuge, as a savior, as a boat and raft rescuing sentient beings, and establishing them on the shore of the great nirvana of humans and gods.
Sentient beings have wrong views, arrogance, and pride like drunken people, bound by the five desires, not cultivating wholesome dharmas.

From here, when their lives end, they fall into the hells, animal realms, and ghost realms, or are born among humans as lowly and poor, experiencing various sufferings like being pierced by a poisoned arrow in body and mind.
Not cultivating wholesome dharmas, they receive these painful retributions.

Next, they observe the heavenly realms.
They observe that the gods have long lifespans and are free from suffering and distress, but when they are about to die, the five signs of decline appear:

First, the flower garlands on their heads all wither; second, their heavenly garments become dusty and dirty; third, sweat naturally appears under their armpits; fourth, their eyes frequently blink; fifth, they no longer enjoy their original abode.

When these signs appear, the newly born heavenly maidens all abandon them from afar, as if discarding grass. The old attending heavenly maidens, with deep feelings of affection, surround them and watch, as if about to give up their lives, sobbing and crying in grief. Each of them approaches and asks with sorrow.
At that time, the heavenly being said:
'I also have no second thoughts of pity for those newly born heavenly maidens. Why do they now abandon me as if I were grass?

You all now grieve and pity me - because of this cause and condition, you give rise to affection for the old and hatred for the new. When the five signs appear, you will surely know that death is approaching. Will you leave this heavenly palace, the delightful sounds, the heavenly colors, fragrances, and delightful pleasures, confused and lost, leaving this palace?'
I cannot remain in the assembly of the gods for long. Is my life about to end today?
Such suffering and distress are like arrows piercing my heart. We have no one to rely on, no one to turn to, no relatives, no master, no place to return to, no one to save us.
Crying out in grief and lamentation:

The Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Maitreya addressed the Buddha, saying:

At that time, the Blessed One told Maitreya Bodhisattva MahÄsattva:

Those who fall into the three evil paths experience immeasurable suffering, which cannot be described or conceived. The lifespan is also like this. In the human realm, after a hundred years, in the heaven of the thirty-three, it is one day and night. When the gods are about to die, they use their heavenly eyes to observe and are all able to know, becoming extremely sorrowful. All their desires and pleasures are lost in an instant. As suffering and happiness each have sixteen parts, the arising of one part of suffering can destroy the sixteen parts of happiness in the heavens.
This is how the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes the suffering experienced by the gods when they are about to die, and gives rise to a mind of great compassion.

One should know that this is the first great compassion of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
How can they be freed from difficulties?
Having thought like this, there is no other way but to enter the ocean and obtain the wish-fulfilling jewel.

Having had this thought, enter the ocean to seek it. Having obtained the wish-fulfilling jewel, place it on a tall banner. It can rain all kinds of precious treasures, clothing, food and drink, incense, flowers, music, and so forth, according to the needs of parents and relatives, satisfying all their wishes.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's giving rise to the bodhi mind and seeking omniscience is also like this.
He thinks like this:
'All sentient beings have been my parents and relatives in past lives. They are now wandering in birth and death and experiencing various sufferings. By what means can they be freed from this?'
Having thought this, there was no other way but to enter the Dharma ocean of the six perfections, seek the wish-fulfilling pearl of omniscience to relieve this suffering.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having contemplated this, definitely know for themselves that they will not regress, and make this vow:

'May I be born in places of suffering and difficulty, and on behalf of sentient beings undergo all kinds of suffering and distress. I do not wish to personally realize liberation and nirvÄá¹‡a, abandoning those sentient beings and seeking my own peace and happiness.
Why is this?

All Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, having sought liberation for themselves and entered nirvÄá¹‡a, are immeasurable, boundless, and innumerable, unable to benefit and delight all sentient beings, and unable to extol the merits of the Buddha's body.

Even if bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are in the three evil paths, they can cause sentient beings to abandon unwholesome actions, cultivate wholesome dharmas, escape from all suffering, and attain liberation, let alone in the human realm.
For this reason, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas benefit and delight all sentient beings in the ten directions.

For this reason, the gods of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, the Great Brahma Heaven King, the Great Self-Existent Heaven, and the sages and non-Buddhists all respectfully make offerings and accept them.
This bodhisattva attains the irreversible mind, praised by the Buddhas of the three times, and is given a prediction of future Buddhahood.

How can it be the same as cultivating the bodhisattva practices of the Great Vehicle, benefiting oneself and others without exception?
For this reason, one increases one's diligence even more. Rather than experiencing immeasurable suffering in the three evil paths, one would never attain nirvÄá¹‡a for oneself and benefit others.

May the evil karma created by all sentient beings of the past, present, and future that should lead to falling into evil realms and experiencing suffering be gathered upon my body and received by me instead.
In the past and present,
I vow to dedicate all the excellent practices and wholesome virtues I have cultivated to all sentient beings, enabling them to quickly realize nirvana.
I vow to give away all my precious wealth, and if beaten, scolded, or humiliated, I will never retaliate but endure it all, wishing for those sentient beings to be free from all offenses and burdens.

For immeasurable, boundless asaá¹ƒkhyeya eons, I vow to carry out difficult and painful practices, and for the sake of sentient beings, I vow to seek unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. I will diligently cultivate meditation and liberation and attain irreversibility.
Moreover, just as the immeasurable, boundless bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the past diligently cultivated omniscience, I too will practice in the same way.
Why is it so?
In order to liberate all sentient beings who transmigrate, and establish them in the unsurpassed liberation of nirvana.

Moreover, I vow that all kinds of sentient beings - whether born from eggs, wombs, moisture, or by transformation; whether having form or formless, whether having perception, no perception, or neither perception nor non-perception - I will cause them all to enter the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.

May all sentient beings fully perfect the six pÄramitÄs, and fully accomplish the unsurpassed Buddha body adorned with a hundred merits, the thirty-two marks, the eighty minor marks, and the halo behind the neck surpassing a hundred thousand suns, which sentient beings delight in seeing and gaze upon without weariness.
Moreover, may all sentient beings in the worlds of the ten directions be adorned with merits all like the Buddha.
He further made this vow:

'I wish to give up this body for the sake of all sentient beings in the Dharma realm. If they beat, scold, or rebuke me, or even bind, torture, or insult me to the point of wanting to end my life, or use me in various ways, I will comply without resistance, and wish that those sentient beings have no karmic hindrances.'
Having made this vow, he further contemplated:

'I wish to quickly fulfill this vow. I also wish that this body will remain in the five destinies, benefiting and bringing peace and joy to all sentient beings. For those without support, I will be their support. For those traveling to other countries, I will be their guide. For those going to sea, I will be their boat and raft. For those crossing ditches and streams, I will be their bridge. For those in the wilderness, I will be their spring and well. For those in the cold, I will be their firewood. For those in the scorching heat, I will be their coolness. For those in the dark, I will be their lamplight.
For those who are tired, I will be their soft bedding. For those who are hungry, I will be their delicious food. For those who are thirsty,
For those who are thirsty, I transform it into sweet juice. For those who are naked, I provide them with clothing. In times of drought and famine,
I cause rain to fall and the five grains to ripen. For those who are sick and suffering, I become a good doctor, curing their illnesses and prolonging their lives.
For those who are lonely, widowed, or orphaned, I become their attendant. For the poor and destitute, I become their hidden treasure.
I follow their activities and dwelling places, never leaving them. For those who travel far, I become their companion, and also their carriage and horse, enabling them to reach their destination.
For those with wrong views, I explain the right Dharma, causing them to abide in right views.
